title: TrueType
content:
**[Indices](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Indices) : [Type Technologies](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Type%20Technologies) : TrueType**

TrueType is a digital [type technology](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/type%20technology) originaly developed by [Sampo Kaasila](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Sampo%20Kaasila) of [Apple, Ink](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Apple), whose remit was to create a custom technology so as to avoid paying royalty fees to use font technologies developed by other parties, as well as to solve some technical limitations of [Adobe's](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Adobe) [PostScript](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/PostScript) based [Type 1](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Type%201) font format. TrueType differs from Type 1 in that it uses [quadratic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/quadratic%20beziers) as opposed to [cubic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/cubic%20beziers) [bezier curves](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/bezier%20curves). TrueType excels at on-screen rendering due to the fact that it can support sophisticated [hinting](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/hinting) instructions. The technology was cross-licensed with a [Microsoft](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Microsoft) replacement for [PostScript](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/PostScript) called [TrueImage](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/TrueImage), but today only TrueType survives. A few years later the format was extended to support [Unicode](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Unicode) and more complex linguistic and typographic behaviours such as automatic ligature substitution and Indic vowel rearrangement. However the new extensions, called [AAT](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/AAT) (Apple Advanced Typography), were not licensed to Microsoft, who then set about creating their own extensions to TrueType (along with [Adobe](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Adobe)), which they called [OpenType](http://web.archive.org/web/20150115042207/http:/typophile.com/wiki/OpenType). The two extensions are incompatible and whilst their feature sets overlap, there are many things that one can do which is impossible with the other.
